member.name: T:Gemstone.Timeseries.ConcentratorBase
member.summary: Measurement concentrator base class.

remarks.para: This class synchronizes (i.e., sorts by timestamp) real-time measurements.

Note that your lag time should be defined as it relates to the rate at which data is coming into the concentrator. Make sure you allow enough time for transmission of data over the network allowing any needed time for possible network congestion. Lead time should be defined as your confidence in the accuracy of your local clock (e.g., if you set lead time to 2, this means you trust that your local clock is within plus or minus 2 seconds of real-time.)

This concentrator is designed to sort measurements being transmitted in real-time for data being sent at rates of at least 1 sample per second. Slower rates (e.g., once every few seconds) are not supported since sorting data at these speeds would be trivial. There is no defined maximum number of supported samples per second - but keep in mind that CPU utilization will increase as the measurement volume and frame rate increase.

member.name: P:Gemstone.Timeseries.ConcentratorBase.MaximumPublicationTimeout
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum frame publication timeout in milliseconds, set to (-1) to wait indefinitely.

remarks.para: The concentrator automatically defines a precision timer to provide the heartbeat for frame publication, however if the system gets busy the heartbeat signals can be missed. This property defines a maximum wait timeout before reception of the heartbeat signal to make sure frame publications continue to occur in a timely fashion even when a system is under stress.

This property is automatically defined as 2% more than the number of milliseconds per frame when the property is set. Users can override this default value to provide custom behavior for this timeout.

member.name: P:Gemstone.Timeseries.ConcentratorBase.ProcessingInterval
member.summary: Gets or sets the desired processing interval, in milliseconds, for the adapter.

remarks.para: This property is normally only used when you need the concentrator to send data at faster than real-time speeds, e.g., faster than the defined . A use case would be pushing historical data through the concentrator where you want to sort and publish data as quickly as possible.

With the exception of the values of -1 and 0, this value specifies the desired processing interval for data, e.g., a timer interval, over which to process data. A value of -1 means to use the default processing interval, i.e., use the , while a value of 0 means to process data as fast as possible.

From a real-time perspective the defines its general processing interval based on the defined property. The frames per second property, however, is more than a basic processing interval since it is used to define the intervals in one second that will become the time sorting destination "buckets" used by the concentrator irrespective of the data rate of the incoming data. As an example, if the frames per second of the concentrator is set to 30 and the source data rate is 60fps, then data will be down-sampled to 30 frames of sorted incoming data but the assigned processing interval will be used to publish the frames at the specified rate.

The implemented functionality of the process interval property will be to respond to values in the following way: ValueResponse
< 0 In this case the default processing interval has been requested, as a result the will be set to false and the concentrator processing interval will be defined based on the currently defined property, e.g., if the frames per second is 30 the processing interval will be 33.33ms.
0 In this case the processing interval has been defined to process data as fast as possible, as a result the property will be set to true and property will be set to false. With a processing interval of zero data is expected to flow into the concentrator as quick as it can be provided. The property will still be used to sort data by time into appropriate frames, but the concentrator will use the reception time of the measurements against the defined lag-time to make sure needed data has arrived before publication and frames will be published at the same rate of data arrival.
> 0 In this case a specific processing interval has been defined for processing data, as a result both the and properties will be set to true. With a specifically defined processing interval, data is expected to flow into the concentrator at a similar rate. The property will still be used to sort data by time into appropriate frames, but the concentrator will use the reception time of the measurements against the defined lag-time to make sure needed data has arrived before publication and frames will be published on the specified interval. If multiple frames are ready for publication when the processing interval executes, then all the ready frames will be published sequentially as quickly as possible.

member.name: P:Gemstone.Timeseries.ConcentratorBase.RealTime
member.summary: Gets the most accurate time value that is available. If = true, then this function will return . Otherwise, this function will return the timestamp of the most recent measurement, or if no measurement timestamps are within time deviation tolerances as specified by the value.
member.remarks: Because the measurements being received by remote devices are often measured relative to GPS time, these timestamps are typically more accurate than the local clock. As a result, we can use the latest received timestamp as the best local time measurement we have (ignoring transmission delays); but, even these times can be incorrect so we still have to apply reasonability checks to these times. To do this, we use the local system time and the value to validate the latest measured timestamp. If the newest received measurement timestamp gets too old or creeps too far into the future (both validated + and - against defined lead time property value), we will fall back on local system time. Note that this creates a dependency on a fairly accurate local clock - the smaller the lead time deviation tolerance, the better the needed local clock accuracy. For example, a lead time deviation tolerance of a few seconds might only require keeping the local clock synchronized to an NTP time source; but, a sub-second tolerance would require that the local clock be very close to GPS time.

member.name: P:Gemstone.Timeseries.Adapters.ActionAdapterBase.RespectInputDemands
member.summary: Gets or sets flag indicating if action adapter should respect auto-start requests based on input demands.
member.remarks: Action adapters are in the curious position of being able to both consume and produce points, as such the user needs to be able to control how their adapter will behave concerning routing demands when the adapter is setup to connect on demand. In the case of respecting auto-start input demands, as an example, this would be false for an action adapter that calculated measurement, but true for an action adapter used to archive inputs.

member.remarks: Action adapters are in the curious position of being able to both consume and produce points, as such the user needs to be able to control how their adapter will behave concerning routing demands when the adapter is setup to connect on demand. In the case of respecting auto-start output demands, as an example, this would be true for an action adapter that calculated measurement, but false for an action adapter used to archive inputs.

member.name: M:Gemstone.Timeseries.Adapters.ActionAdapterBase.SetTemporalConstraint(System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Defines a temporal processing constraint for the adapter.
member.param: Defines a relative or exact start time for the temporal constraint.
Defines a relative or exact stop time for the temporal constraint.
Defines any temporal parameters related to the constraint.

remarks.para: This method defines a temporal processing constraint for an adapter, i.e., the start and stop time over which an adapter will process data. Actual implementation of the constraint will be adapter specific. Implementations should be able to dynamically handle multiple calls to this function with new constraints. Passing in null for the and should cancel the temporal constraint and return the adapter to standard / real-time operation.

The and parameters can be specified in one of the following formats: Time FormatFormat Description
12-30-2000 23:59:59.033Absolute date and time.
*Evaluates to .
*-20sEvaluates to 20 seconds before .
*-10mEvaluates to 10 minutes before .
*-1hEvaluates to 1 hour before .
*-1dEvaluates to 1 day before .

member.name: P:Gemstone.Timeseries.Adapters.ActionAdapterCollection.RespectInputDemands
member.summary: Gets or sets flag indicating if action adapter should respect auto-start requests based on input demands.
member.remarks: Action adapters are in the curious position of being able to both consume and produce points, as such the user needs to be able to control how their adapter will behave concerning routing demands when the adapter is set up to connect on demand. In the case of respecting auto-start input demands, as an example, this would be false for an action adapter that calculated measurement, but true for an action adapter used to archive inputs.

member.name: P:Gemstone.Timeseries.Adapters.ActionAdapterCollection.RespectOutputDemands
member.summary: Gets or sets flag indicating if action adapter should respect auto-start requests based on output demands.
member.remarks: Action adapters are in the curious position of being able to both consume and produce points, as such the user needs to be able to control how their adapter will behave concerning routing demands when the adapter is set up to connect on demand. In the case of respecting auto-start output demands, as an example, this would be true for an action adapter that calculated measurement, but false for an action adapter used to archive inputs.

member.name: P:Gemstone.Timeseries.Adapters.AdapterBase.ConnectionString
member.summary: Gets or sets key/value pair connection information specific to this .

remarks.para:
Example connection string using measurements defined in a  table:
inputMeasurementKeys={FILTER ActiveMeasurements WHERE Company='GSF' AND SignalType='FREQ' ORDER BY ID};
outputMeasurements={FILTER ActiveMeasurements WHERE SignalType IN ('IPHA','VPHA') AND Phase='+'}


            Basic filtering syntax is as follows:


                {FILTER <TableName> WHERE <Expression> [ORDER BY <SortField>]}


            Source tables are expected to have at least the following fields:
NameTypeDescription.
IDNVARCHARMeasurement key formatted as: ArchiveSource:PointID.
PointTagNVARCHARPoint tag of measurement.
AdderFLOATAdder to apply to value, if any (default to 0.0).
MultiplierFLOATMultiplier to apply to value, if any (default to 1.0).

member.name: M:Gemstone.Timeseries.Adapters.AdapterBase.ParseTimeTag(System.String)
member.summary: Parses a string formatted as an absolute or relative time tag.
member.param: String formatted as an absolute or relative time tag.
member.returns: representing the parsed string formatted as an absolute or relative time tag.

remarks.para: Relative times are parsed based on an offset to current time (UTC) specified by "*".

The parameter can be specified in one of the following formats: Time FormatFormat Description
12-30-2000 23:59:59.033Absolute date and time.
*Evaluates to .
*-20sEvaluates to 20 seconds before .
*-10mEvaluates to 10 minutes before .
*-1hEvaluates to 1 hour before .
*-1dEvaluates to 1 day before .
*+2dEvaluates to 2 days from .

member.exception: parameter cannot be null or empty.
does not contain a valid string representation of a date and time.

member.summary: Gets or sets the desired processing interval, in milliseconds, for the adapter.
member.remarks: With the exception of the values of -1 and 0, this value specifies the desired processing interval for data, i.e., basically a delay, or timer interval, over which to process data. A value of -1 means to use the default processing interval while a value of 0 means to process data as fast as possible.

member.name: M:Gemstone.Timeseries.Adapters.AdapterBase.SetTemporalConstraint(System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Defines a temporal processing constraint for the adapter.
member.param: Defines a relative or exact start time for the temporal constraint.
Defines a relative or exact stop time for the temporal constraint.
Defines any temporal parameters related to the constraint.

remarks.para: This method defines a temporal processing constraint for an adapter, i.e., the start and stop time over which an adapter will process data. Actual implementation of the constraint will be adapter specific. Implementations should be able to dynamically handle multiple calls to this function with new constraints. Passing in null for the and should cancel the temporal constraint and return the adapter to standard / real-time operation.

The and parameters can be specified in one of the following formats: Time FormatFormat Description
12-30-2000 23:59:59.033Absolute date and time.
*Evaluates to .
*-20sEvaluates to 20 seconds before .
*-10mEvaluates to 10 minutes before .
*-1hEvaluates to 1 hour before .
*-1dEvaluates to 1 day before .

member.name: M:Gemstone.Timeseries.Adapters.AdapterCollectionBase`1.SetTemporalConstraint(System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Defines a temporal processing constraint for the adapter collection and applies this constraint to each adapter.
member.param: Defines a relative or exact start time for the temporal constraint.
Defines a relative or exact stop time for the temporal constraint.
Defines any temporal parameters related to the constraint.

remarks.para: This method defines a temporal processing constraint for an adapter, i.e., the start and stop time over which an adapter will process data. Actual implementation of the constraint will be adapter specific. Implementations should be able to dynamically handle multiple calls to this function with new constraints. Passing in null for the and should cancel the temporal constraint and return the adapter to standard / real-time operation.

The and parameters can be specified in one of the following formats: Time FormatFormat Description
12-30-2000 23:59:59.033Absolute date and time.
*Evaluates to .
*-20sEvaluates to 20 seconds before .
*-10mEvaluates to 10 minutes before .
*-1hEvaluates to 1 hour before .
*-1dEvaluates to 1 day before .

member.name: P:Gemstone.Timeseries.Adapters.FacileActionAdapterBase.LagTime
member.summary: Gets or sets the allowed past-time deviation tolerance, in seconds (can be sub-second).

remarks.para: Defines the time sensitivity to past measurement timestamps.
The number of seconds allowed before assuming a measurement timestamp is too old.
This becomes the amount of delay introduced by the concentrator to allow time for data to flow into the system.

member.exception: LagTime must be greater than zero, but it can be less than one.

member.name: P:Gemstone.Timeseries.Adapters.FacileActionAdapterBase.LeadTime
member.summary: Gets or sets the allowed future time deviation tolerance, in seconds (can be sub-second).

remarks.para: Defines the time sensitivity to future measurement timestamps.
The number of seconds allowed before assuming a measurement timestamp is too advanced.
This becomes the tolerated +/- accuracy of the local clock to real-time.

member.exception: LeadTime must be greater than zero, but it can be less than one.

member.name: P:Gemstone.Timeseries.Adapters.FacileActionAdapterBase.RespectInputDemands
member.summary: Gets or sets flag indicating if action adapter should respect auto-start requests based on input demands.
member.remarks: Action adapters are in the curious position of being able to both consume and produce points, as such the user needs to be able to control how their adapter will behave concerning routing demands when the adapter is set up to connect on demand. In the case of respecting auto-start input demands, as an example, this would be false for an action adapter that calculated measurement, but true for an action adapter used to archive inputs.

member.name: P:Gemstone.Timeseries.Adapters.FacileActionAdapterBase.RespectOutputDemands
member.summary: Gets or sets flag indicating if action adapter should respect auto-start requests based on output demands.
member.remarks: Action adapters are in the curious position of being able to both consume and produce points, as such the user needs to be able to control how their adapter will behave concerning routing demands when the adapter is set up to connect on demand. In the case of respecting auto-start output demands, as an example, this would be true for an action adapter that calculated measurement, but false for an action adapter used to archive inputs.

member.remarks: Use your local system clock as real time only if the time is locally GPS-synchronized, or if the measurement values being sorted were not measured relative to a GPS-synchronized clock. Turn this off if the class is intended to process historical data.

member.name: E:Gemstone.Timeseries.Adapters.IAdapter.ProcessException
member.summary: Event is raised when there is an exception encountered while processing.

remarks.para: Implementations of this interface are expected to capture any exceptions that might be thrown by user code in any processing to prevent third-party code from causing an unhandled exception in the host. Errors are reported via this event so host administrators will be aware of the exception. Any needed connection cycle to data adapter should be restarted when an exception is encountered.
is the exception that was thrown.

member.name: P:Gemstone.Timeseries.Adapters.IAdapter.ProcessingInterval
member.summary: Gets or sets the desired processing interval, in milliseconds, for the adapter.
member.remarks: With the exception of the values of -1 and 0, this value specifies the desired processing interval for data, i.e., basically a delay, or timer interval, over which to process data. A value of -1 means to use the default processing interval while a value of 0 means to process data as fast as possible.

member.name: M:Gemstone.Timeseries.Adapters.IAdapter.SetTemporalConstraint(System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Defines a temporal processing constraint for the adapter.
member.param: Defines a relative or exact start time for the temporal constraint.
Defines a relative or exact stop time for the temporal constraint.
Defines any temporal parameters related to the constraint.

remarks.para: This method defines a temporal processing constraint for an adapter, i.e., the start and stop time over which an adapter will process data. Actual implementation of the constraint will be adapter specific. Implementations should be able to dynamically handle multiple calls to this function with new constraints. Passing in null for the and should cancel the temporal constraint and return the adapter to standard / real-time operation.

The and parameters can be specified in one of the following formats: Time FormatFormat Description
12-30-2000 23:59:59.033Absolute date and time.
*Evaluates to .
*-20sEvaluates to 20 seconds before .
*-10mEvaluates to 10 minutes before .
*-1hEvaluates to 1 hour before .
*-1dEvaluates to 1 day before .

is total number of unprocessed measurements.

Event arguments containing number of queued (i.e., unprocessed) measurements in the source adapter.

Time-series framework uses this handler to monitor the number of unprocessed measurements in output adapters.

remarks.para: Defines the time sensitivity to past measurement timestamps.

remarks.para: Defines the time sensitivity to future measurement timestamps.

This becomes the tolerated +/- accuracy of the local clock to real-time.

member.name: M:Gemstone.Timeseries.Adapters.OutputAdapterBase.Flush
member.summary: Blocks the current thread, if the is connected, until all items in queue are processed, and then stops processing.

remarks.para: It is possible for items to be added to the queue while the flush is executing. The flush will continue to process items as quickly as possible until the queue is empty. Unless the user stops queuing items to be processed, the flush call may never return (not a happy situation on shutdown).
The does not clear queue prior to destruction. If the user fails to call this method before the class is destructed, there may be items that remain unprocessed in the queue.

member.name: P:Gemstone.Timeseries.Adapters.OutputAdapterBase.ProcessingInterval
member.summary: Gets or sets the desired processing interval, in milliseconds, for the output adapter.
member.remarks: With the exception of the values of -1 and 0, this value specifies the desired processing interval for data, i.e., basically a delay, or timer interval, over which to process data. A value of -1 means to use the default processing interval while a value of 0 means to process data as fast as possible.

member.summary: Returns the detailed status of the data input source. Derived classes should extend status with implementation specific information.

member.summary: Stops this and disconnects from data output stream.

member.name: P:Gemstone.Timeseries.Adapters.OutputAdapterBase.SupportsTemporalProcessing
member.summary: Gets the flag indicating if this implementation supports temporal processing.
member.remarks: For output adapters that archive data it is assumed that the desired behavior will be to not support temporal processing since the data being processed has already been archived (i.e., no need to attempt to re-archive old data). As a result the default behavior for an output adapter is to not support temporal processing when is true. If you have an output adapter that you want to support temporal data processing independent of the value, then override this property and force the base value to the desired state.

is total number of unprocessed measurements.

member.name: M:Gemstone.Timeseries.Statistics.DeviceStatisticsHelper`1.Reset
member.summary: Resets the member variables used to track statistics for the device wrapped by this helper.
member.remarks: Call this when the connection to a device has been reset to mark a starting point for statistics gathering. Since the method keeps track of the time it was last called, it is necessary to call this method during long periods of downtime where Update was not being called in order to avoid momentary, unexpectedly large values to be calculated for measurements expected.

member.name: M:Gemstone.Timeseries.Statistics.DeviceStatisticsHelper`1.Reset(System.Int64)
member.summary: Resets the member variables used to track statistics for the device wrapped by this helper.
member.param: The current time, in ticks.
member.remarks: Call this when the connection to a device has been reset to mark a starting point for statistics gathering. Since the method keeps track of the time it was last called, it is necessary to call this method during long periods of downtime where Update was not being called in order to avoid momentary, unexpectedly large values to be calculated for measurements expected. This method is preferred when tracking statistics for multiple s to reduce the number of calls to .

member.summary: Updates the statistics for the number of measurements received and the number of measurements expected in the wrapped by this helper.
member.remarks: Call this periodically, preferably on a slow timer (e.g., once per second), in order to update the , , and statistics.

member.name: M:Gemstone.Timeseries.Statistics.StatisticsEngine.RegexMatch(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Determines whether the given signal reference matches the signal reference regular expression using the given suffix.
member.param: The signal reference to be matched against the regular expression.
The suffix used by a particular type of statistic.
member.returns: Flag indicating whether the signal reference matches the regular expression.
member.remarks: The format for signal reference of statistics is: ACRONYM!SUFFIX-ST#, where ACRONYM is the acronym of the measurement's source, SUFFIX is the suffix given as a parameter to this method, and # is an index used to differentiate between statistics with the same source and type.

member.name: M:Gemstone.Timeseries.Statistics.StatisticsEngine.TryLookupStatisticSource(System.String,System.String@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Attempts to lookup statistic source and signal index from a measurement .
member.param: Signal reference.
Statistic source category as defined in Statistics table Source column.
Statistic signal index as defined in Statistics table SignalIndex column.
member.returns: true if lookup succeeds; otherwise, false.
member.remarks: The statistic source acronyms used in measurement signal references are defined dynamically by statistic sources during registration. This function returns the source category, as defined in the Statistic table, for a given signal reference to allow for reverse lookups. As a result, user will need to make sure that all statistic sources have been registered before calling this function in order to receive accurate results.

member.name: M:Gemstone.Timeseries.Statistics.StatisticsEngine.Unregister(System.Object)
member.summary: Unregisters the given source, removing it from the list of statistic sources so that it no longer generates statistics.
member.param: The adapter to be unregistered with the statistics engine.
member.remarks: Sources that implement do not need to explicitly unregister themselves from the statistics engine. The engine automatically unregisters them by attaching to the event.
